Ru/AC catalyst used in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction has several drawbacks such as poor dispersion, metal loss, serious carbon deposition, and insufficient active sites. To address these issues of traditional Ru/AC, in this study, the supported Ru-Lx/AC catalysts were synthesized by the coordination of ruthenium precursor and several structural triazine ligands. The complexation of heteroatomic structure to Ru atom formed a local active domain, which is more conducive to the synergistic adsorption and activation of the initial reactants, and further optimizes the reaction microenvironment. The spatial topological structure with conjugated structures effectively promoted the transfer of electrons between the heteroatoms and the ruthenium precursors, facilitating the stabilization of active Ru species. The newly developed synthetic process also increased dispersion of reaction components and impeded the sintering of ruthenium components promoted by the local structural forces. The optimum Ru-1,3,5-triazine/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited 162% higher acetylene conversion than the benchmark Ru/AC catalyst. The significantly improved activity and stability of the optimized catalyst will have a huge application prospect in industry. Graphical abstracts Efficient acetylene hydrochlorination: The coordination between ruthenium and heteroatom ligands promotes the transfer of electrons between the heteroatoms and the metal precursor, ensuring the continuous and efficient catalysis of the catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene hydrochlorination Ru-based catalysts Triazine ligands Coordination Enhanced performance 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is considered to be the third largest engineering plastic in the world attributing to its excellent chemical and physical properties in construction, healthcare, electronics, automotive, and other fields [1–3]. PVC at industrial scale is mainly prepared by the ethylene method, acetylene method, and ethane method. In some oil-rich countries, production at industrial scale by the acetylene method uses the mercury-based carbon-supported catalyst; however, the toxicity of mercury poses a huge hazard to the environment and human health. In addition, HgCl2 is volatile at the reaction temperature, causing severe mercury loss in the reactor, thus rapidly deactivating the catalyst [4,5]. China has acceded to the Minamata Convention on Mercury [6]. Under the technical and economic feasibility of mercury-free catalysts, the application of mercury catalysts in the PVC industry will be banned in 2025. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a non-mercury and efficient alternative catalyst to realize the sustainable and green development mode of PVC industry. In recent years, many non-mercury carbon-supported noble metal (such as Au, Pt, Pd, and Rh) catalysts have been extensively studied for the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination [5,7-12]. For instance, Hutchings and co-workers demonstrated that gold-based catalysts generally exhibit higher activity in the acetylene hydrochlorination. Especially, the gold-based catalyst containing auxiliary metal additive (such as Cu, La, Ba, Li, Cs, Bi, and Sn) further enhanced the catalytic performance of the catalyst [13–21]. Subsequently, Hutchings and co-workers reported different gold complexes to enhance catalyst stability, thereby improving catalyst life. Among them, Au-S composite catalyst (0.1 wt% Au) was prepared by using Na3Au(S2O3)2 as the precursor, demonstrating excellent catalytic performance in industrial experiments [22]. Ionic liquids have the advantages of good solubility, low volatility, weak intermolecular interaction, and strong polarity, and thus they are used to modify metal catalysts. Li and co-workers synthesized an Au-IL/AC catalyst by coordinating an ionic liquid [23] and then designed an Au-Cu-IL/AC catalyst [15]. The introduction of CuCl2 effectively inhibits the reduction of high valence Au by acetylene, in particular, uniform film formed by ionic liquid on the surface of catalyst, which retard the coke deposition. However, the high cost of the catalyst caused by the soaring gold price deters a growing number of factories from promoting the high-loaded gold catalysts. Next to research on gold catalysts with very low loading, other relatively cost effective metals (including Ru [24,25] and Cu [26]) have been studied intensively, among which Ru-based catalysts were studied to a larger extent, demonstrating a suitable activity and stability. Ruthenium catalysts are more economical because ruthenium (0.001 ppm) is not as abundant as Au (0.0031 ppm) in the earth's crust[27], but the price of commercially available RuCl3 is about one-third to one- fifth of the price of HAuCl4, and it is mainly used as a catalyst in the petrochemical industry, unlike Au, where less than 10% of Au is used for other purposes, including catalyst preparation, most of which is used for currency manufacturing and luxury goods processing. Zhu and co-workers calculated the reaction barriers of MClx (M = Hg, Au, Ru; X = 2,3) in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction by density functional theory (DFT) and showed that the reaction barriers of HgCl2, AuCl3, and RuCl3 catalysts were 16.3, 11.9 and 9.1 kcal mol−1, respectively, indicating that ruthenium-based catalysts may replace mercury-based catalysts in the hydrochlorination of acetylene [28]. Subsequently, many scholars considered the application of ruthenium-based catalyst in the acetylene hydrochlorination. For instance, our group designed and developed different ruthenium-based catalysts, among which the Ru1Co3/SAC catalyst demonstrated excellent conversion of acetylene (>95%) and VCM selectivity (>98%), and Co(III) components effectively evolved low-valent Ru components to high-valent Ru components [24]. Subsequently, we studied the effect of the modified carrier by nitrogenous nitrogen groups (such as -NHN, -NH2, and -NO2) to the catalytic properties of the ruthenium-based catalysts [29], and the heteroatoms could change the electronic properties of the starting material and further change its interaction with the metal and the reactants. The increased content of the active component in the catalyst enhanced the adsorption capacity for HCl and the desorption capacity for VCM. Although much work has been done to improve catalyst activity and stability, rational design of a cost-effective heterogeneous non-mercury catalyst still remains a major challenge. Recently, we designed a highly efficient 1%Ru-based catalyst (1Ru-5IL5/AC), achieving acetylene conversion up to 99.51%, and there is almost no significant drop in the catalyst activity after the 200 h reaction [30]. Li and co-workers designed and prepared different active phases Ru-based catalysts and proved RuCl2N as an effective active phase co-activated by acetylene and hydrogen chloride. In addition, they successfully introduced nitrogen-containing ligands (formation of Ru-N species) to promote the activation of HCl and further improve the catalytic efficiency. The turnover frequency (TOF) value of the catalyst reached a record 5263 h − 1 [31]. Unlike the common belief that monoatomic metal catalysts are more conducive to catalyzing the reaction, a recent study has shown that RuOxCly nanoparticles (1.5 nm) deliver an important contribution in a nitrogen-doped carbon-supported Ru/N-C catalyst, which is easily deactivated because of the redispersion of catalytic nanoparticles into single atoms and coke deposition on the carbon surface. Calcination at 1073 K in an inert atmosphere can form a graphite shell around the Ru particles to prevent their redispersion, and the introduction of oxygen in the reaction process can inhibit the carbon deposition on the catalyst [32]. Therefore, the reported data are contentious regarding the origin of the reactivity of Ru-based catalysts supported on activated carbon on account of the complexity caused by the abundantly concomitant Ru species, including Ru0 clusters, RuO2, and Ru3+ cationic species, on the surface of individual carrier. The effectiveness of ruthenium-based catalysts for the acetylene hydrochlorination reportedly varies, and no consistent conclusion has been reached regarding the choice of catalyst support or host and treatment. Furthermore, although many remarkable studies have been reported to inhibit catalyst deactivation, in order to meet the requirements of industrial production, the stability and service life of ruthenium-based catalysts need to be further improved. Ruthenium ions have similar equivalent s, p, and d orbitals. Therefore, the hybrid orbital is easier to form a hybrid orbital with strong bonding ability, accepts the lone pair of electrons of the heteroatom ligand, and static electricity has a stronger influence on the ligand. The unsaturated d orbitals in Ru ions have considerable deformability and strengthen the coordination bond between the metal atom and the ligand. Triazine ligands are important heterocyclic compounds, rich in heteroatoms. The heteroatoms synergize with the metal ions to form a chelate compound having a stable cationic resonance structure and a spatial topology. In this study, the triazine ligand was selected to coordinate with the Ru precursor with the aim to form a local active domain owing to the abundance of heteroatomic structures in the ligand structure, and this could further stabilize cationic Ru species during the catalytic reaction process. This study could provide directions for the development of economical mercury free catalysts and further engineering studies toward an industrial process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Unfiltered activated carbon was provided by S. S. Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Ruthenium trichloride hydrate (RuCl3•3H2O) was provided by Macklin. The triazine ligands were provided by Aladdin. All the chemicals used in this study met the experimental requirements and were used without any further purification. 2.2 Catalyst design and preparation Pickling of the initial activated carbon (HCl solution:1 moL L− 1) was carried out to remove impurities and vacuum drying at 130 °C for 12 h [33], and then the processed sample is labeled as AC. AC supported 1 wt% Ru-Lx/AC (x = 1, 2, 3, and 4) catalysts (Table S1) were prepared by the impregnation process method [34]. First, RuCl3•3H2O (1 g) was added to a beaker with 100 mL of deionized water to obtain the Ru solution (0.004 g mL−1). Second, the Ru solution (11.6 mL) was pipetted into a clean beaker, and a certain amount of triazine ligand (mole ratio of Ru to ligand was 1:1) was dissolved in deionized water (18.4 mL, 80 °C), and the two solutions were mixed for 30 min to obtain Ru-L solution. Finally, the prepared AC and Ru-L solution was poured into a round-bottom flask with stirring, refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h, and further dried in a vacuum oven at 75 °C for 10 h. Lx denotes L1: 1,3,5-triazine, L2: melamine, L3: cyanuric acid, L4: trithiocyanuric acid. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation In a customized fixed-bed microreactor (inner diameter 8 mm), the catalytic performance of the catalyst was tested under normal pressure. Before the reaction, the entire reaction pipeline was purged with N2 (25 mL min−1) for half an hour to remove the gas impurities present in the reaction system. Then, the catalyst was activated with a stream of HCl (25 mL min−1) while slowly heating the catalyst bed to 180 °C (reaction temperature). Then, pure HCl gas (34.5 mL min−1) and pure C2H2 gas (25.0 mL min−1) were forced into the reactor through the 5 mL catalyst bed. In order to remove unreacted HCl gas, the reaction product passed through a plastic absorption bottle filled with NaOH solution (2 mol L− 1), and acetylene conversion and the selectivity to VCM were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC-2014C gas chromatograph. 2.4 Catalyst characterizations UV–visible spectroscopy (UV–Vis) analysis of liquid samples was performed using a Shimadzu UV-2600 dual-beam spectrophotometer with a data acquisition wavelength range 200–800 nm. The absolute Ru content in the catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Varian 725-ES). Before the test, a measured amount of catalyst was digested in aqua regia. Texture properties of the catalysts were obtained from the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) experiment using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020C instrument. Before the test, the catalyst sample was degassed at 160 °C and 50 mbar for 5 h. Thereafter, the analysis was conducted at a P/Po range 0.01–1.0 in liquid nitrogen. The catalyst sample was subjected to thermogravimetry–differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) analysis using a simultaneous thermal analyzer (NETZSCH STA 449F3, Germany). These data were collected from 35 °C to 900 °C (10 °C min−1) in the air gas atmosphere. The active species were characterized by X-ray diffractometry (XRD) using a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer (Germany, λ = 0.15418 nm), and the data collection is in the 2θ range 10–90° The transmission electron microscope (TEM) test was performed using a JEOL JEM2010 electron microscope. The catalyst sample powder was put into ethanol to make it uniformly dispersed by ultrasonication, and the resulting mixture was placed into the copper grid coated with carbon film to prepare the TEM catalyst test sample. The distribution of active components from the perspective of atomic level was observed by recording a high-angle circular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) image using an FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin electron microscope. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test was performed using a PHI-5100 Versa Probe instrument. The Ru 3p, N 1s, O 1s, and S 2p spectral data were recorded, and the measured data were calibrated using the C 1s peak (284.8 eV). The full width half maximum of Ru 3p is 2.5 eV, and the background type is Shirley. FTIR experiments with CO adsorption characterization was conducted on the Bruker VERTEX70 infrared spectrometer in Germany. The 15 mg catalyst was reduced at 300 °C in pure H2 (20 mL min−1) atmosphere for 2 h, and reduced to room temperature in Ar atmosphere (20 mL min−1). Then CO was introduced for adsorption for 0.5 h, and the spectrum was scanned at an interval of 5 min. Finally, it was purged with Ar, and the spectrum was scanned at an interval of 5 min until the infrared peak intensity remained unchanged. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) test was carried out using a Chembet PULSAR TPR/TPD instrument to determine the proportion of Ru species with different valence states in the unreacted catalyst. Weigh the catalyst (0.1 g) into a sample tube, and the temperature was varied from 45 °C to 900 °C (10 °C min−1) under 30 mL min-1 H2/Ar (10%-H2) atmosphere. At the same time, the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) test was carried out using the same instrument to evaluate the ability of the unreacted catalyst to adsorb reactants. Weigh the catalyst (0.1 g) into a sample tube and increase the temperature from 45 °C to 900 °C (10 °C min−1) in the He atmosphere (30 mL min−1). 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) simulation DFT calculation was performed by using the B3LYP function, and the molecular geometry of all model complexes was optimized without constraints. Except for Ru, all atoms (C, H, N, O, S, and Cl) use 6–31 G (d) basis set. As for Ru, which is described by LANL2DZ basis set and realized effective core potential (ECP) [35–37]. Frequency calculations were carried out at the same theoretical level to determine all the stationary points as transition states (an imaginary frequency) or minimum (a zero imaginary frequency), and thermal correction free energy was provided at 298.15 K and 1 atm. The Intrinsic Reaction Coordinates (IRC) were calculated for all the transition states to confirm that these structures do indeed connect two related minimums. In order to obtain higher-precision electron energy, SDD was used to calculate the single-point energy of Ru at the B3LYP level, and the 6–311+G(d,p) basis set was used for other atoms. The Gibbs free energy of each substance was obtained by the thermal correction of the free energy and the more accurate single-point energy of the gas phase. All the calculations were performed using Gauss 16 software package. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of all catalysts Fig. 1 shows the catalytic activity of all the catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. Activated carbon with no loading exhibited only 7.42% acetylene conversion rate, with the least catalytic activity. When Ru components were loaded, the acetylene conversion rate of the Ru/AC catalyst reached 53.6%. It is worth noting that after the introduction of triazine ligands, catalytic performance including acetylene conversion and selectivity toward VCM improved. In particular, 1,3,5-triazine (L1) significantly improved the catalytic activity of the Ru-based catalyst, reaching the acetylene conversion rate to 96.15%. To explore the effect of different heteroatoms for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, the structural triazine-based ligands were introduced, compared to the catalytic activity of Ru/AC, and the activity of the catalysts improved to different degrees by introducing the ligands containing different heteroatomic functional groups. It is concluded that the structure of the triazine ligand may affect the electronic properties of the active component of the catalyst, and the introduction of the heteroatom-containing ligands may change the intensity of coordination with the active component, requiring further characterization and analysis to verify. 3.2 Interaction between Ru species and triazine ligands Considering that carbon carrier would greatly interfere with the absorbance signal of metal-ligand, only the UV–vis absorption spectra of several solutions were collected (Fig. 2 ). A distinct absorption peak at 242 nm corresponds to the π bond in the triazine ring, and can be recognized in the 1,3,5-triazine solution [30]. The d-d transition phenomenon of Run+ causes the Ru solution showing two absorption peaks at 301 nm and 498 nm. In addition, Fig. 2 shows that the characteristic absorption peaks of Run+ in Ru-L solution redshifted, and the central peaks moved to 266 nm and 355 nm, respectively. This indicated a chelation between the ligand and Ru to form the Ru complex [38]. XPS characterization can be adopted as an effective means to further demonstrate complex coordination. Ru 3p spectra are divided into four types in Ru/AC catalysts (Table 1 and Figure S1), namely Run+ (n > 4), Ru4+, Ru3+, and Ru0, with the binding energy positions of 461.2 eV, 463.3 eV, 464.1 eV, and 467.2 eV, respectively [24,39]. In view of the complexity of the functional groups on the surface of the carrier and its chemical properties, the supported RuCl3 precursor is easily disproportionated into Ruz+ (z > 0) and Ru0 components, which are considered as the main catalytic component and the component that deactivates the catalyst respectively. The comparison indicated that after the reaction, the introduction of ligands increases the stability of ruthenium active species. In particular, the introduction of triazine-based heteroatomic ligands changes the electronic property of central Ru atom, and can be demonstrated by the positional shifting of the Ru species and heteroatomic binding energies (Figures S1-S4), and this also provides further evidence for the Ru-L chelation. 3.3 The structural property of the prepared Ru catalysts The loading capacity of the catalyst to the active site will be affected by the specific surface area and physical structure. Table 2 lists the physical structure data for all the catalysts. No loading carrier exhibits a relatively large specific surface area (SBET, 1011 m2 g− 1) and total pore volume (VP, 0.53 cm3 g− 1), which is slightly reduced by the ruthenium precursor loading [40]. In particular, the test data in Table 2 and pore size distribution (Figure S5 and Figure S6) indicate that micropores dominate the pore structure of the host, and there is a small amount of mesoporous structure. Moreover, the introduction of ligands has no significant effect on the average pore size of the host, and this observation was also be verified by the H4 hysteresis loops of all the catalysts (Figure S7). However, the increase in the SBET and VP in the Ru-L catalysts may be caused by the concave and convex distribution on the surface of the catalyst after the ligand with large steric hindrance allocated to the ruthenium components. After 24 h of reaction, the increased Sext/SBET and Dpore (Table 2) accompanied by the decreased SBET, VP, and Smicro/SBET, indicating that the micropores might have blocked by the deposition of by-products [40]. Therefore, the introduction of the ligand indeed retarded the magnitude of the decrease of SBET and VP. Thermogravimetric analysis is an effective means to determine the amount of coke deposition on the catalyst [41]. Fig. 3 shows that fresh and used Ru-L1/AC catalysts had a slight weight loss due to desorption of weakly adsorbed substance (for example, moisture) on the carbon surface before 100 °C. When the temperature exceeds 394 °C, the weight loss rate of the catalysts increased significantly mainly because of self-combustion of the activated carbon at high temperatures. Therefore, the mass change of the catalyst between 100 °C and 394 °C reflected the amount of coke deposition on the catalyst rather than the decomposition of the ligand (Figure S8) [42]. To prove that the presence of ligands effectively reduced the formation of coke deposits during the reaction, the coke deposition of the Ru/AC catalyst and other catalysts during the reaction was also analyzed (Figure S9 and Table 3 ). The Ru/AC catalyst exhibited higher amount of carbon deposition (6.7%) during the reaction, and the introduction of the ligands, especially L1 (1.9%) effectively inhibited the coke deposition. This is consistent with the analysis of the texture parameters of the various catalysts and is also closely related to the different structures and catalytic activities of the active substances formed by the coordination of different ligands with Ru precursors. 3.4 Dispersibility of active components and its crystalline phase The coordination of heteroatomic ligands with the Ru precursor aims to disperse and anchor the Ru active species. To verify this hypothesis, the Ru active species were characterized by XRD and TEM. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of all the catalysts, indicating that the catalyst before and after the reaction has three amorphous diffraction peaks of activated carbon at 24.2°, 43.5°, and 79.2° (2θ), indicating that the particle size is below the XRD detection limit of 4 nm, and that the Ru active components are evenly distributed on the carrier [43]. The HAADF-STEM image directly showed the Ru particles in the catalysts (Figs. 5 a–e). To observe the dispersion of active components more intuitively, the HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 5f) and the element mapping images (Figs. 5g–m) of the Ru-L1/AC catalyst were obtained. The introduction of L1 achieved uniform dispersion of all the active Ru components. All the catalysts exhibited a sintering phenomenon after the reaction, particularly, the average particle size of the Ru/AC catalyst increased from 2.90 nm (Figure S10a) to 3.36 nm (Figure S10b). Specifically, the Ru-L1/AC catalyst's average particle size was the smallest (1.69 nm, Figure S10d). 3.5 Interaction between the host and formed active species Fig. 6 shows the TPR profile for all fresh catalysts. The data in Fig. 6 illustrate the effect of the ligands on the valence state of Ru species and the interaction between the ligand and the active components. Since the O-functional group on the support is reduced, all the catalysts show typical reduction peaks in the range 420–850 °C. Three characteristic reduction peaks appeared at 139, 231, and 318 °C for the Ru/AC catalyst, attributing to the reduction of Rup+ (p ≥ 3) active components [24]. After the addition of the triazine ligands to the system, compared to the Ru/AC catalyst, the temperature at which the active component is reduced increases significantly, and most obvious increase was observed for Ru-L1/AC, further proving a strong interaction between the active components and the support, and the characteristic peaks of the Ru-based catalyst containing the triazine ligands are sharper than the Ru/AC catalyst, indicating that the presence of triazine ligands make the active components uniformly dispersed on the surface of the carrier, and this observation is consistent with the TEM analysis result. It is worth mentioning that the introduction of triazine ligands significantly increases the percentage of ruthenium active species. This can be qualitatively judged by calculating the peak areas corresponding to the Ru species of various valence states. Therefore, with the addition of triazine ligands, Ru-Lx/AC catalysts increased the stability of ruthenium active species, which were widely considered to be the dominant species for hydrochlorination of acetylene [24,25]. XPS was used to further study the valence states of Ru species in different catalysts as shown in Figure S1 and Table 1. Triazine ligands exist in the catalyst system, and the Ru0 species in the Ru-L1/AC catalyst are transformed into high-valent Run+ species, including the newly emerging Rum+ (1 < m <3) species. In addition, the relative content of high- valent Ru species in Ru-L1/AC increased significantly, which is consistent with the TPR analysis. This may be the main reason of the improved catalytic activity of Ru-L1/AC catalyst than other Ru-based catalysts. In addition, after the Ru/AC catalyst reacted for 24 h, the signal-to-noise ratio significantly reduced probably because the deposited coke during the reaction covered the active components and thus accompanied by severe loss of the active components. The percentage of Ru0 species in the Ru/AC catalyst increased from 20.6% to 32.9%, indicating that the reduction of high-valent Ru by acetylene continuously decreased the catalytic performance. CO-DRIFTS characterization can further confirm the existence of different oxidation states of ruthenium components in the catalyst. The linear adsorption vibration peak of CO on metal Ru is located in the low frequency region (LF) of 1990–2060 cm−1, and the high frequency (HF) peak at 2060–2156 cm−1 is attributed to the adsorption of polycarbonyl groups formed by CO on the partially oxidized or electron-deficient Ru species. As shown in Fig. 7 , three peaks appear at 2011, 2075, and 2156 cm−1, corresponding to Ru0-CO, Run+(CO)x, and Run+(CO)2, respectively [44]. In addition, the absence of level band around 1800 cm−1 further indicates that there is no cluster formation; the level band around 2011 cm−1 corresponds to the adsorption of CO by isolated Ru nanoparticles, and those around 2075 cm−1 and 2156 cm−1 correspond to the linear adsorption of CO by Ru single atoms. For triazine ligands, the structure conforms to the 4n+2 rule specified by the Huckel rule and has six delocalized electrons, and the three N atoms adopt the same sp2 hybridization as the three C atoms, all of which are in the same plane; therefore, they have the traditional aromaticity. Therefore, the coordination of Ru with the N atom on the triazine ring led to the transfer of the electrons between the ligand and RuCl x via Cl-Ru-N bridge, stabilizing the relative content of the ruthenium active species, and ensuring the sustainable high catalytic performance [27,45]. In particular, when the H atoms on the triazine ring were replaced by hetero atom substituents (-NH2, -OH, -SH), the steric effect of heteroatom functional groups (-NH2, -OH, -SH) weakened the coordination of Ru with the N atom on the triazine ring. By comparing the used Ru-Lx/AC catalysts, the disappearance of Ru0 species in the Ru-L1/AC catalyst means that the stable complex formed by the Ru species and the 1,3,5-triazine effectively resisted the reduction of the active component; therefore, in this reaction, it exhibits excellent catalytic performance compared to other Ru-based catalysts. 3.6 Adsorption performance of the prepared catalyst to the initial reactants The presence of ligands in the catalytic system affects the electronic properties of the metal and the performance of the fresh catalyst to adsorb the initial reactants. The HCl-TPD curves indicated that the desorption peak of HCl for AC is in the range 105–199 °C (Fig. 8 a). Notably, compared with the Ru catalyst without ligands, the introduction of ligands triggered the polymorphic adsorption of HCl and significantly improved the adsorption performance of fresh catalysts for HCl. Among them, Ru-L1/AC showed the best adsorption performance, and further proved that the stable Cl-Ru-N bond formed by the stable coordination between Ru precursor. 1,3, 5-Triazine promoted the electron transfer of ligands to RuCl x species via Cl-Ru-N bridge, thus promoting the central Ru species to stabilize in an oxidation state and resulting in a great improvement in the adsorption performance of HCl [45,46]. Similarly, the Ru loading triggered the polymorphic adsorption of the catalyst to C2H2 (Fig. 8b). For the qualitative analysis of the peak area, the interaction of the triazine ligands with the Ru precursor also changed the adsorption capacity of the fresh catalyst to C2H2. Furthermore, comparing 1,3,5-triazine as the ligand, the introduction of hetero atom functional group (-NH2, -OH, -SH) ligands weakened the coordination of Ru with the N atom on the triazine ring, decreasing the adsorption of the initial reactant by the catalyst. 3.7 Research on catalytic mechanism The DFT simulation reveals the interaction mechanism between L1 and Ru species (Fig. 9 ). In addition, the relative energy of Ru monomer, dimer, and trimer was calculated to prove that the system is the most stable when the Ru component exists in the form of dimer (Figure S11). The stable Ru dimer catalyst first captures C2H2 molecules to form the complex M1. The energy released in this step is 18.1 kcal mol−1 (Fig. 9). After capturing C2H2 and HCl molecules, the absorbed energy is 4.6 and 9.8 kcal mol−1, respectively. M3 undergoes the transition state M-TS1 to produce the target product (Fig. 10 ), with an energy barrier of 27.2 kcal mol−1. When L1 appears in the reaction system, the stable Ru-complex A1 is formed first, and A1 captures C2H2 and HCl molecules to form complex A3, and the absorbed energy is 3.8 and 8.5 kcal mol−1 (Fig. 9). A3 undergoes the transition state A-TS1 to produce the target product (Fig. 10), with an energy barrier of 25.9 kcal mol−1, indicating that the introduction of L1 improves the properties of the Ru-based catalyst and is consistent with the experimental results. In addition, the average Mulliken charge of Ru, N, and Cl atoms before and after the coordination were read from DFT simulation calculation. As shown in Table S2, after the complex was formed, the electrons on the Cl and N atoms increased, which indicates that the electrons were transferred between the ligand and RuCl x via Cl-Ru-N bridge, leading to the increase in electron cloud density of Cl and N and further promoting the central Ru species to stabilize in an oxidation state. 3.8 Long-term stability test of optimal Ru-L1/AC catalyst Considering the potential for large-scale industrial applications, the ratio of ruthenium to ligand was optimized (Figure S12), due to economic considerations for catalysts. In addition, the long-term stability tests were also conducted for the optimal Ru-L1/AC (Ru:L1 = 1:2) catalyst (Fig. 11 ). The conversion rate of the catalyst to acetylene reached as high as 99.65%, and the selectivity to VCM is close to 100%. In particular, the acetylene conversion rate of Ru-L1/AC catalyst was still maintained at 85% after 300 h of service life testing, and this is far better than the benchmark Ru/AC catalyst under the same conditions. In addition, the pilot sideline evaluations show that although Ru-based catalysts are not as good as Au-based catalyst in terms of cost advantages (Table S3), considering only one-way life and not considering the recycling of precious metals, Ru-based catalyst is also one of the potential mercury-free catalysts considering the wide application of Au in various industries, the small amount of Au that can be allocated for the preparation of catalysts and the significant reduction of the cost of Ru-L1/AC catalyst compared with Ru/AC. Therefore, the excellent catalytic properties of Ru-L1/AC catalyst have potential for industrial application. 4 Conclusion Carbon-supported Ru-Lx/AC catalysts were successfully prepared using a series of structural triazine-based ligands and applied to the acetylene hydrochlorination. The activity test results showed that the Ru-1,3,5-triazine/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity. The UV–vis, BET, XPS, TGA, TPD, ICP-AES, XRD, TEM (HAADF-TEM), and H2-TPR techniques combined with the DFT calculations indicate the coordination between Ru species and heteroatom ligands, promoting the electron transfer between the ligand and RuCl x via Cl-Ru-N bridge, leading to the increase in electron cloud density of Cl and N and further promoting the central Ru species to stabilize in an oxidation state. This stabilized Ru active species, made the Ru active species difficult to reduce, and increased the relative content of Ru active species. This stable coordination allows the atomic-level dispersion of the active species on the carrier, and the resulting catalyst thus had the advantages of low cost, convenient preparation, environmental friendliness, thus providing a valuable reference for the preparation of high-efficiency catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. coredata.dc:description: Ru/AC catalyst used in acetylene hydrochlorination reaction has several drawbacks such as poor dispersion, metal loss, serious carbon deposition, and insufficient active sites. To address these issues of traditional Ru/AC, in this study, the supported Ru-Lx/AC catalysts were synthesized by the coordination of ruthenium precursor and several structural triazine ligands. The complexation of heteroatomic structure to Ru atom formed a local active domain, which is more conducive to the synergistic adsorption and activation of the initial reactants, and further optimizes the reaction microenvironment. The spatial topological structure with conjugated structures effectively promoted the transfer of electrons between the heteroatoms and the ruthenium precursors, facilitating the stabilization of active Ru species. The newly developed synthetic process also increased dispersion of reaction components and impeded the sintering of ruthenium components promoted by the local structural forces. The optimum Ru-1,3,5-triazine/AC (Ru-L1/AC) catalyst exhibited 162% higher acetylene conversion than the benchmark Ru/AC catalyst. The significantly improved activity and stability of the optimized catalyst will have a huge application prospect in industry.
coredata.dc:title: High-efficiency catalysis of Ru-based catalysts assisted by triazine-based ligands containing different heteroatoms (N, O, S) for acetylene hydrochlorination
